body: There's another version tag in `setup.py`, somehow I haven't find a way to centralize it in one place as importing airflow in setup.py was creating problems.

This should do it: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/200

I just want to make sure this won't affect our production jobs (by setting our schema to empty string in our connections) before merging

Fixing a bug and generalizing the idea here:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/201
Good catch. Thanks!

Hi,

My scenario is :
- One job is fetching an endpoint to get access_token via OAuth
- My second job needs this access_token to perform the query on a second endpoint.

I could do this in the same job but i had like to separate them.

Regards,
I'd like the Jobs, Logs, and other views to support a state called "Expired", instead of having them in "Running" but have a heartbeat which is like 2 days old.

depends_on_past only depends the task. I want to depends the past dag.
I also tried the ExternalTaskSensor, however the ExternalTaskSensor cannot specified time

The quick solution is to modify the url parameter `num_runs=25` to something higher. Eventually the UI should have 2 form elements for anchor_date (default = now) and num_runs (default=25). I'll rename this issue and keep it open until we get to it.

Here:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/models.py#L1576

I need to add docstrings to some of these methods so that they surface in the API docs...

Since it's a property you can just use `mydag.filepath`

Agreed. I see how this is confusing. We need a watchdog that keeps an eye on jobs without heartbeat (maybe part of the scheduler daemon) and expires or fails tasks. I think I also need to manage the SIGINT on a task to update the corresponding job. Currently it only flags the task instance as failed on SIGINT/SIGTERM.

In the meantime, the task instance table is the authority on state and jobs / logs aren't used in the logic and are informational indicators around it.

default_args is how you set default arguments for the tasks in your DAG.

Check out the "Default Arguments" section in the tutorial
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/docs/tutorial.rst

Default arguments can be overridden at the task level.
The feature described here should fix this: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/203

I'll rename this task to add a `previous_schedule` boolean param to `ExternalTaskSensor`, in the meantime you can emit a signal of some sort (DB flag, trigger file, empty partition in a hive signal table) on one side and put a sensor on the other DAG.
Thanks :+1:

Thanks for reporting this bug. I'm not sure why it only affects postgres, but this should do it: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/97c98b12f517b06c21f834841cb5cf4c0b59255d

You may have to recreate your table with the new code or just alter it straight in the db cli.
Oh Cool!

Hi!
You need to connect your operators with a  `set_upstream` or `set_downstream` command.

For example.

```
OP1  = BashOperator( ... )
OP2 = PythonOperator( ... )
OP2.set_upstream(OP1)
OP3 = EmailOperator( ... )
OP3.set_upstream(OP2)
```

This will create a chain, one of the simplest DAG topologies : `OP1 ==> OP2 ==> OP3`

You don't need pools or priorities. Just run `airflow scheduler` and let it execute your DAG. If you haven't created these dependencies, then the scheduler will just likely assume they are not related and execute them in random order. When you set it up as I am shown above, the scheduler will not execute downstream operators until and unless upstream operators have succeeded.

Seems like a very small unit of work, you could easily squeeze both in the same `PythonOperator`.

Are you concerned about minimizing the number of hits on the first endpoint?
Done, worked for me, thank's

Hi! 
Thanks for your quick reply.

Sorry if I wasn't clear enough. I need to keep the order of jobs execution but my jobs doesn't depend on each other and they never should be skipped. In your example OP3 will not run if OP2 fails. But what if I need to just ignore OP2 failure and execute OP3 after it?

It sounds like you want the operators to make a best-effort attempt at doing some work. Regardless of the outcome, you want the chain to proceed. In this case, I would just use a Python operator for all of my tasks. In each Python operator, I would catch and eat any errors or exceptions raised inside the task code body so that the next operator could proceed. In the end, all of your PythonOperator tasks will appear on the UI as having succeeded, even if they did not. If you actually want to retain information about what passed and what failed, it sounds like we need support for a new configuration parameter at the task level : `continue_on_failure = True`. Is that what you are asking for? If so, then it does sounds dubious at first glance, especially if I think about typical ETL-style workloads. In ETL-style work-loads, it's generally a bad practice to `continue_on_failure`. However, I can envisage use-case where you are trying to load some 3rd party data or keep some cache fresh, and you don't have control over the availability of that 3rd party data source. In these cases, best-effort is all you can do. And in such cases, having an accurate history, especially a visual history such as shown below, would be very useful. If this is what you are thinking, then I would add my vote.

BTW, as a user of this project, I don't believe `continue_on_failure` exists today. It would need to be a feature request. I'd suggest changing the title to `Feature Request : Support optional continue_on_failure task instance semantics`

I think we are on the same page. I have a bunch of tasks that provide updates for the database. These tasks can die because of bad input, 3rd party data unavailability or some unexpected throw. I want to give them a chance to prepare updates but even if all of them fail I still need to rebuild the database.

This behavior can be achieved with `continue_on_failure` you described. And I believe we have some other options:
1. Create a sensor like `ExternalTaskSensor`. The only difference will be filter arguments: 
   https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/master/airflow/operators/sensors.py#L127
2. Use a single-slot pool and priority_weights. I think it is the most proper way, but I couldn't make it work.

Now that I understand what you are trying to accomplish, both of your approaches seem valid. It does look like no. 2 is a bug. I'd file that as a separate bug and link that bug here. It would be good to provide your code or sample code in the bug -- I find that always results in the fastest turn-around from the Airbnb team.
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/209
@nouseforacode @r39132
Very cool. @nouseforacode can you beta test this and give feedback? I don't have an immediate need for this feature.
What is the intuition around `execution_delta` and why is it needed?

If you want to poke for a relative date, most likely previous execution, as in "if the last task of yesterday's DAG execution is done, move forward".

It's essentially a `depends_on_past` for on any other tasks.
Hyperlinks are hyper-ok!

I realized the installed version of airflow is 1.2.0, and does not have the SimpleHttpOperator
How do I install latest airflow version 1.2.1 ?

When I try to upgrade using sudo pip install --upgrade airflow, it eventually gives me an error -
"IOError: Cannot find krb5.h, enusre you have installed krb5 development library.
Cleaning up...
Command python setup.py egg_info failed with error code 1 in /tmp/pip_build_root/python-krbV"

I have ubuntu 14.04 and already tried installing krb5 using -
sudo apt-get install krb5-kdc krb5-admin-server

But the installation error does not go away. Any suggestions?

@kapil-malik  I believe this is a case of the version on Pypi being a bit behind the documentation (and the repository). The latest version on Pypi seems to have been published on July 1st where as the http operator would appear to have been introduced on July 2nd.

https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commits/master/airflow/operators/http_operator.py

@syvineckruyk yes, thanks for the reply. Indeed, I found it myself too. However, the upgrade of existing airflow installation - OR - a fresh airflow installation on another box gives me the error I mentioned above. Any suggestions around the same?

@kapil-malik 
Well you won't be able to upgrade past 1.2.0 using Pypi at the moment since that is the latest published version.

As for the error you are seeing above ... not sure not using Ubuntu and have never seen that error ... is this being triggered by the Pypi upgrade command or are you using the source from Github ?

If from source what command triggers the error ?

By the Pypi upgrade command, and also from a fresh Pypi installation on another Ubuntu box.
Will try to explore what might be the issue.

Btw, to use the HttpOperator, can you suggest timeline for the next published release?
OR, if I want to build from Github, are there any defined steps?

Again, is there a mailing list for such naive queries ?

@kapil-malik not aware of timeline but I would not expect it to be very long ... 

As for your issue with Pypi ... i have not tried on Ubuntu ... but I believe this may be related to a missing python-dev installation (including dependencies). If you are working on a box that you can experiment on I would try that. But this is just a hunch.

Installing from Github is pretty straightforward but you run the risk of running an unstable version ... 
clone the repo, 
install the requirements (pip install -r requirements.txt )
install airflow (python setup.py install or python setup.py develop)

No mailing list that I know of for the moment.

I just pushed `1.3.0` out to pypi.

I don't know where the kerberos dependency comes from, I don't see it anywhere in my airflow install. Which higher level package is trowing this error?

Thanks for the github steps @syvineckruyk and for the update @mistercrunch 
kerberos dependency is coming from snakebite (in dependency.txt)  ... I can reproduce it with sudo pip install snakebite
I was able to get past it by sudo apt-get install libkrb5-dev
Will update once I am able to complete a fresh install successfully.
I should move this as `extras_require` then. Thanks for your patience troubleshooting this, it will make it much easier to install Airflow for the wave of installers!

Related commit is out:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/commit/3d51ef727645e7332333c5aaaf5f00738461b963?diff=unified

it missed the train to 1.3.0 on pypi though, I'll push another version later this week.
rebased merge conflicts resolved

Hi @mistercrunch 
Thanks for the update. New release on pypi works like a charm. Here are the additional manual steps on Ubuntu 14.04 with python 2.7, python2.7-dev (pip) installed for sudo pip install airflow -
1. export LANG=en_GB.UTF-8
I had LANG=en_US.UTF-8, which gives - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/10561923/unicodedecodeerror-ascii-codec-cant-decode-byte-0xef-in-position-1
2. sudo apt-get install libkrb5-dev (this would go away I believe)
Fixes error message : Cannot find krb5.h
3. sudo apt-get install libsasl2-dev
Fixes error message : Cannot find sasl.h

Needed for airflow initdb -
4. sudo pip install amqp, anyjson

I can see http operator and connection in 1.3.0. Can close this issue now.
Thanks

We're all using `LANG=en_US.UTF-8` and it's fine, I'd be curious to see the stack traces for some of these errors.

About `libsasl2-dev`, I assume you installed `airflow[hive]`, I think sasl is needed by pyhs2.

I'll try installing on a fresh Ubuntu install and see what kind of troubles I hit.
I'm surprised that there isn't some sort of authentication required. I'll give it a spin tomorrow and see if it work against our Slack instance!

My guess is the `queued` state is unrelated to the `ExternalTaskSensor` changes. You must be using pools, is there room in your pool?

I'll start including release notes, for the past you have to diff out tags. Each pypi release has had a clear tag and you can easily diff them. (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/releases) This is more noisy than a typical maintainer curated release notes. I'll start including those in future releases.

I believe Celery requires 2 SIGTERM signals, the first one corresponds to a warm shutdown, where the main process waits for the tasks in the threads to finish. The second is a cold shutdown where it sends SIGTERMs to the subprocesses.  I noticed it sometimes leaves zombie processes around.

This command kills zombies:
`ps auxww | grep 'celery worker' | awk '{print $2}' | xargs kill -9`

 Maybe I need to add some logic in Airflow to handle this properly since apparently Celery doesn't.

More info here:
http://celery.readthedocs.org/en/latest/userguide/workers.html
Can you share the content of the log file? I'm confused about where the "out of 4" comes from. Is default_args modified anywhere else?

That is true, add pool, it work.

Thank you very much, close it

Many thanks to you both! I am testing now a similar Operator which I created soon before #209. Everything looks good except a small issue with Airflow UI. ExternalTaskSensor assumes that you have a dependency to another DAG, so it doesn't draw any dependency, using it on the same DAG with a previous date is a bit of a hack. 

The only dependencies drawn are the ones coming through the normal task dependencies mechanism.

I was trying this schedule_interval example and cannot get it to work with the current pypi version (1.0.1) and github version. If I pass in the schedule_interval to DAG it applies it, but as part of the default args it is not used.

I'd use a 12 hours `schedule_interval` anchored on a 00:00 start_date and derive the `TimeSensor` with your specific logic. Something like: 

```
class CustomTimeSensor(TimeSensor):
    def poke(self, context):
        # pseudocode
        # if the time of context['exectution_date'] is 00:00 and current_time >= 10:30am
        #     return True
        # elif the time of context['exectution_date'] is 12:00 and current_time >= 3:30pm
        #     return True
        # else 
        #     return False
```

Then your processes downstream can just depend on this and should trigger at 10:30 for the morning run and 3:30 for the afternoon one.

Thanks for all the details, it should make it much easier to zero in on what's going on (actually, what is NOT going on...).

Oh and your expectations are right, though typically Airflow isn't used to do every minute-type batch jobs, but I understand you did this for testing purposes.

The `schedule_interval` is really just how often the DAG should run and it's generally bad to change this around because if you go from minutes to hours, or to days it will add the `schedule_interval` to the last run and things might not line up across tasks. If task A is at 00:33 and task b is at 00:35 when you switch to a daily job, the dependencies will not line up in time when adding a day to both. Anyhow. For testing purpose every minute _should_ work, though daily should work just as well. Just make sure to clear the history and set your `start_date` to where you want it as you change the schedule.

So it looks like your scheduler is aware of your DAG, and the worker too. First thing I would do would be to look into the log file on the worker (if you cannot see). Was that job triggered by the scheduler or the UI "run" button?

Is the scheduler emitting messages? Are the workers picking them up? If so it may be that the worker and the scheduler are pointing to different metadata databases, make sure the configurations are in sync.

I think that an `impersonate` flag in BaseOperator could be a decent generic way to help around security and attribution of "who is running what", even if Airflow is triggering the job.

The way `impersonate` would work is that the job on the worker would `sudo su {task.owner}` prior to running it. This assumes unix based roles and security to be deployed on workers. Of course many systems (take mysql for instance) don't support unix-type authentication.

Impersonate could be forced to `True` for given operators using the undocumented `policy` feature described in `settings.py`

Try this:

``` python
import airflow

# create the local variable
var = airflow.models.Variable(key='key', val='val')

# get the database session
session = airflow.settings.Session()

# add the variable
session.add(var)
session.commit()

# [you should see it in the web interface now]

# retrieve it
airflow.models.Variable.get('key')

# delete it
session.delete(var)
session.commit()
```

I think the broader issue here is the difficulty of of building run-time dynamic pipelines, where the tasks and dependencies vary based on factors discovered during the run. I don't see a great way to handle that in Airflow. Here are some rambling thoughts...

This manifests in two ways:
1. a task whose parameters depend on information discovered by earlier tasks (as described by @griffinqiu and @kwent)
2. a task whose existence depends on information discovered by earlier tasks (haven't seen anyone mention this yet, but I think it's the larger issue -- basically a superset of the first one)

Issue 1) could be solved with a convenience function for serializing data to the database. That could be injected into the context, as @mistercrunch wrote, or simply persisted in a table (it seems like Variables, or something like Variables, are the right approach here. Using callbacks and context requires users to first store objects in context, then write a callback... it seems like the logic could be wrapped up nicely in a function and sanitized/checked for compatibility in the process. I will open a separate issue to discuss this.) I think, broadly speaking, that it's healthy to split up any logical task into small pieces even if the unit of work is small, if only because it leads to better monitoring of progress and errors.

Issue 2) is much harder and @griffinqiu's issue could be viewed as a variant of it. Basically, we don't know in advance what tasks we need to run. I think the most common variant of this is "vertical" scaling (vertical in the context of the web UI), where I know what tasks I will run, but I don't know how many or with what parameters (i.e. how many vertical rows I'll see in the web UI).

For example:
- I want to process every file in a directory (local, FTP, etc.). I don't know the filenames in advance because someone may have put a new file in there since the last time. I also don't want to reprocess files I've already seen. As nice as it would be to have a formal contract with all data, often that's just not the case -- files show up in funny ways and times. So I know the tasks I need to run, but not the input or count
- I want to run a pipeline with parameters that were produced by another process or pipeline. I don't know in advance how many different sets were produced, so I don't know how many times to run the pipeline. For example, build aggregations of data every X minutes, where X is an array of values generated externally that varies day to day. I don't know X until I reach that point in the pipeline and access it.

Airflow is built around the concept of DAG discovery taking place entirely separately from running them. So this is hard to reconcile with the idea of dynamic DAG building. But perhaps a `DAGOperator` could generate a DAG at runtime and run it ad-hoc, then delete it. However I'm not sure how it would play with the interface (in terms of displaying progress and also knowing if tasks have already been run on subsequent runs).

Food for thought... this is a problem we deal with in our pipeline so I will continue to think about it and would love any other perspective.

I like this idea a lot (https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/170#issuecomment-128401782). 

I think `Variable` provides the basic infrastructure to achieve this and we could build on top of it. See https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/220, #133 and #12.

However, I'm not sure exactly what Variables are being used for but they don't feel like the right place for this specific use -- first because they're publicly/globally visible and we'd end up horribly polluting that namespace, and second because they don't enforce the dag/task/datetime id that this would require.

But I think they light the path. So I'd propose the following:
1. based on the code that defines Variables [here](https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/blob/1c322b007ec24aeaf9889be44f057d38af3f6c49/airflow/models.py#L1980), create a new table called `State` (or something) keyed by (dag_id, task_id, ds, time_) [_in case there are multiple runs per day?]
2. add class functions similar to `Variable.get()` which store and retrieve `State`s
3. add `get_state()` and `set_state()` methods to `PythonOperator` which handle json serialization/loading and creating the proper table key.

So users could do something like this:

``` python
def my_func(x, **kwargs):
    # get the calling task
    task = kwargs['task']

    # set_state handles json conversion and generating the 
    # appropriate keys (task_id, dag_id) for storing the value 
    task.set_state('my list', [1, 2, 3])

    # get_state retrieves the most recently saved state called 'my value', 
    # optionally restricting the query to a certain task, dag, or date.
    #
    # in this case, we're only getting 'my value' if it was written by a task called
    # 'my_other_task'
    state = task.get_state('my value', task_id='my_other_task', dag_id=None, date=None)
```

Maybe with a little magic we can get rid of needing to access kwargs/pass context, but let's leave that for the future. In fact, I guess users could do that by calling `State.set()` directly, but then they'd have to pass the `task_id` and `dag_id` that the `task` method handles automatically.

@r39132 your point number 3 could be handled with some of the callback functions that I believe were recently handled.

Critically, all the plumbing to do this already exists thanks to `Variable`; just need to write the utility functions. If this is interesting I'll take a crack at it.
Maybe `save`/`load` or `store`/`retrieve` are the right semantics instead of `get`/`set`... open to suggestions!

Very nice! 

A few related ideas:
- What about using pickles instead of json? SqlAlchemy has a nice pickle type. We could actually put more complex objects in there.
- The name "TaskValue" is confusing to me since it's really attached to a task **instance**. What about xcom for "cross communication"
- The get and set methods could also exist at the TaskInstance object where you already have the `execution_date` parameter
- This will require an entry in the docs, probably under the "Concepts" section for now (once the implementation is clarified and settles)
- All operators return value (if any) could be left behind for other tasks to read, if it's a pickle it can even be an object, though we have to be careful for people not to put gigantic objects in there.
- could do the javascript style api where `task_instance.xcom(key="foo")` returns the value, and  `task_instance.xcom(key="foo", value="bar")` sets the value

Now I'm thinking this can also be used in templates `{{ task_instance.xcom(task_id="other_task", key="return_value") }}`!

@mistercrunch glad you liked it ... this was a small preview ... working on a slackbot now for airflow that will actually sit in channels as a user ... broadcast messages from airflow to whatever channels it's in and take commands as input .. im currently trying to add all the functionality of the CLI.

@mistercrunch glad you like this direction... 'draft' is definitely the operative word, this needs to be smoothed out a bit.

To your points:
1. Great call, pickles would be much better! I've never used the SqlAlchemy pickletype before -- is [this the one](http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/rel_1_0/core/type_basics.html#sqlalchemy.types.PickleType) you mean? Looks like we just make a column of type `PickleType` and store the pickles there... is it really that straightforward?
2. Yup, the name is no good. I actually called it State at first before realizing there was something else in the module called State... led to all kinds of issues. XCom works for me. (xcom all lower case?)
3. I can put methods on TIs. The larger question is, how will people actually call this? The two places that seemed obvious to me off that bat were inside `python_callable` (which is why the xcom class method is needed) and inside `BaseOperator.execute()` (which is why the `BaseOperator` method is needed). What else am I missing? (and how can those signatures be simplified). Your use cases (`task_instance.com()`) look natural, so I feel like that's a better direction than mine, but I want to walk through how the user gets the `task_instance` too... I know I'm revealing my Airflow novice status here)
4. Once we have all the names and methods down, I'll write a doc/tutorial.
5. This is a really interesting idea. Maybe with some sort of size check on the pickle to protect against huge objects (if that can be done quickly, I'm not sure). Getting values is, in general, easier for users than setting them -- so if the setting were handled automatically by `return` it would go a long way toward usability (and, I'm guessing, cover the vast majority of use cases where intermediate results aren't important).
6. I'll admit this makes me a little nervous because the get/set isn't obvious to me... feels a little un-Python. It might be possible to hack a `property` such that `val = task_instance.xcom(key="foo")` is the getter and `task_instance.xcom(key="foo") = val` is the setter. Might not be obvious either.

Templates... that's a whole new level. I'll let you handle that!

I'll try to pick this back up next week after the Py3 stuff is (hopefully) knocked out.

Also, pinging @r39132 @griffinqiu @kwent @oren-yowza @Susanne-ywz @seibert @azaroth42 in case they don't get notified.

1. yes, I use it in models.py
2. `XCom` for the class and `xcom_get` and `xcom_set` maybe for related methods
3. I'd say methods on both BaseOperator and TaskInstance, for TIs you don't need to specify `execution_date` but you can if you want to go in the past (most use cases should be same schedule or previous I would guess). I like the idea of assuming that `dag_id` and `task_id` are also the same as the the caller's if not specified. You can push Or pull, meaning I could set a message at a destination task, or set one on my own tasks for other tasks to pull.
4. We can assume people are adults and can hurt their network/DB if they want. It'd be hard to define a sound limit. Maybe warn above a certain size but that's not a needed feature.
5. Yeah, not very pythonesque, let's stay explicit. XCom object can have `set` and `get` methods, and BaseOperator and TaskInstance can both have `xcom_get`, and `xcom_set`

Templates come for free since task and task_instance are already in the context for all templates everywhere! More about what's in the context which is sprinkled everywhere, but most useful in all templates and operators execute methods and callbacks.
http://pythonhosted.org/airflow/code.html#macros

We're currently sketching a solution for this here, please join the PR and comment on the implementatoin details as it shapes up:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/232
I think it's taking shape nicely with a very integrated model.

Now keep in mind that Airflow is a batch workflow engine, not a realtime stream processing engine like Storm or Spark Streaming, and that the current model works extremely well, at scale, for what it is intended. A similar system at Facebook that inspired some of the design decisions behind Airflow is used by hundreds of data people everyday to satisfy a very large array of use cases. I'm convinced there would be a way to solve your use cases with Airflow as it is today, but agree that cross task communication can be more elegant in many cases.

@azaroth42, we use Airflow to trigger Spark, Cascading, Hive, MR, ML, Ruby, Python, MySql, and all sorts of other tasks at Airbnb. Airflow is the orchestra director, it glues all of these systems together in a nice symphony

For the chunks of pipelines that you'd want to be very dynamic and shape-shifting (I'd like more specific use-cases still to understand what you are all up to!), maybe something external to Airflow like some platform, program, or service can satisfy these use cases. Assuming that this thing works in batch, Airflow would just coordinate this service with others.

Current pypi is 1.3.1 I believe, but schedule_interval is a DAG only param for now, I could add heterogenous schedule_interval support easily but I need to put some safeguards on it first:
Related: https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/issues/221

For reference, we're in solution mode here:
https://github.com/airbnb/airflow/pull/232
